whatIsSharing.title: What is Medical Cost Sharing?
whatIsSharing.description: Medical cost sharing is a healthcare model where members contribute monthly amounts that are used to pay for each other's eligible medical expenses. It's not traditional insurance, but a community-based approach to healthcare costs.
keyPoints: Members share each other's eligible medical expenses
Lower monthly costs compared to traditional insurance
Faith-based exemption from ACA individual mandate
No network restrictions - choose your own doctors

faq.question: What is an Initial Unsharable Amount (IUA)?
faq.answer: The IUA is similar to a deductible in traditional insurance. It's the amount you pay out-of-pocket before the community begins sharing your medical expenses. Different plans have different IUA amounts.

faq.question: How is health sharing different from insurance?
faq.answer: Health sharing is not insurance. It's a community-based approach where members voluntarily share each other's medical expenses. There are no guarantees of payment, but our community has a strong track record of sharing eligible expenses.

faq.question: Who is eligible for health sharing?
faq.answer: Generally, anyone can apply for health sharing. Some plans may have health questions or lifestyle requirements. Pre-existing conditions may have waiting periods before they become shareable.

faq.question: Can I keep my current doctor?
faq.answer: Yes! Health sharing plans typically don't have provider networks, so you can see any licensed healthcare provider. You have the freedom to choose the doctors and hospitals you prefer.

disclaimers: Medical cost sharing is not traditional health insurance and is not regulated by state insurance departments.
Members should be aware that sharing of medical expenses is voluntary and there are no guarantees that expenses will be shared.
Rate estimates are informational only. Eligibility and final sharing amounts are determined at enrollment and subject to the member guidelines.
MPB Health facilitates access to qualified health share programs and is not itself a Health Care Sharing Ministry (HCSM).
